questions.question: Which of these is the default integer type in Rust?
questions.explanation: If not specified, Rust defaults to i32 for integers as it's generally the fastest.

questions.question: What is the difference between a Tuple and an Array?

options.text: Arrays can change size, tuples cannot
Tuples can hold different types, arrays must hold the same type
Arrays use parentheses, tuples use brackets

questions.explanation: Tuples are collections of multiple types, while arrays are collections of the same type.

questions.question: How do you access the first element of a tuple named 'my_tup'?
questions.explanation: Tuples use dot notation followed by the index to access elements.

questions.question: Which type would you use for a single character like 'A'?
questions.explanation: The 'char' type is used for single Unicode characters and uses single quotes.

questions.question: What happens if you access an array index that is out of bounds?

options.text: It returns a random value from memory
The compiler catches it (if possible) or it panics

questions.explanation: Rust provides safety by checking bounds at runtime and panicking if you try to access memory that doesn't belong to the array.
